title: Adaptive Prototype Model for Attribute-based Multi-label Few-shot Action Recognition
author: Juefeng Xiao (Wuhan University), Tianqi Xiang (Wuhan University), Zhigang Tu (Wuhan University), ..., Zhigang Tu (Wuhan University)
relevance_why: The techniques for multi-attribute recognition and generalization in few-shot learning could be applicable in audio classification tasks, specifically in enhancing audio event detection where various attributes are relevant.
background: Few-shot action recognition involves identifying actions in videos based on very few annotated examples, while also recognizing multiple related attributes from a richer dataset.
contribution: This paper introduces the Adaptive Attribute Prototype Model (AAPM) to solve the issue of attribute-bias and improve recognition accuracy in multi-label classification tasks, achieving state-of-the-art results in action recognition.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods often focus on single attributes or introduce bias due to specific training conditions.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work employs both textual features and visual features in the recognition process while mitigating confusion between different attributes through innovative prototype construction.

key_innovation: The model incorporates a Text-Constrain Module that utilizes textual attributes to guide visual representation during training, thereby enhancing accuracy in multi-label settings.
real_world_impact: This study could improve the accuracy of action recognition systems in real-world applications such as surveillance, sports analytics, and human-computer interaction.
limitations: No limitations explicitly mentioned by the authors.

new_terms.attribute-bias: **Attribute-bias** refers to a tendency of models to favor certain attributes over others due to training conditions, which can lead to reduced generalization across diverse tasks.
new_terms.prototype-confusion: **Prototype-confusion** describes ambiguity when matching query data to multiple prototypes that share similar attributes, complicating the decision process in classification tasks.

open_sourcing: The project and dataset are available at an anonymous account https://github.com/theAAPM/AAPM
